body:
Still happening, currently failing around 10% of builds.

Recent ASAN failures (happening on epoll1, epollex, epollsig)
https://sponge.corp.google.com/invocation?id=f7ee6170-f1c6-4116-81d5-962a6c854b2a
https://sponge.corp.google.com/invocation?id=2016ec16-c4ef-4485-b2b4-f2766323d672
https://sponge.corp.google.com/invocation?id=f1dc0c30-e0f7-49dc-b974-04eafeb6f027
https://sponge.corp.google.com/invocation?id=63a07ada-2e40-4465-a58a-fc8270faf228

Recent TSAN failures:
https://sponge.corp.google.com/invocation?id=546743dd-6c4d-427c-b156-74dc7b55ba77
https://sponge.corp.google.com/invocation?id=4548574d-988e-4a4f-8c48-48eddf34570e
https://sponge.corp.google.com/invocation?id=e1bc63ef-1718-4574-9225-a96f946e4f51

All ASAN failures complain about heap-use-after-free
```
2018-01-28 21:20:44,537 I0128 21:20:43.163893779   27119 ev_epoll1_linux.cc:114]     grpc epoll fd: 3
```

The `bm_fullstack_streaming_ping_pong` flavor of the test is flaky for the same reason (e.g. https://sponge.corp.google.com/target?id=f1dc0c30-e0f7-49dc-b974-04eafeb6f027&target=github/grpc/cpp_linux_asan_native&searchFor=&show=ALL&sortBy=STATUS)
This is our top flake (failing > 16% of builds). Any updates?

How I understand this:

The write is trying to update the statistics:
https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/e6cf0aeff4979e5ff2501e7fe5e2fdf926350452/test/core/util/passthru_endpoint.cc#L85

But they have been deleted as part of the InProcessCHTTP2 instance (destructor has been called).
https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/e6cf0aeff4979e5ff2501e7fe5e2fdf926350452/test/cpp/microbenchmarks/fullstack_fixtures.h#L263
Looks like just making sure that the `grpc_passthru_endpoint_stats stats_` won't get deleted before passthru endpoint's me_destroy should be enough to prevent the race. I'll see what I can do.
Ok, I haven't had a chance to look at it yet but was going to take a shot today. If you take it over that's great
Note: failures in `bm_fullstack_unary_ping_pong` has been seen since the fix, but it's not the original problem and it's much less frequent. Filed as  https://github.com/grpc/grpc/issues/14310.
